title: BP eyes carbon capture project in Australia
text:
But like Mr Dale, Mr Ismayilov underlined the technology, which is far from commercial, "needs governmental support to accelerate its deployment".

He also revealed that BP is also "actively exploring opportunities" in the hydrogen sector in Australia, describing that as "another work in progress".

Solar power has already become a major area for the energy player in Australia through its Lightsource BP venture, which has 800 megawatts of power at various stages of development in Australia.

"This is important, as solar could generate 12 per cent of total global power by 2040, in a scenario based on recent trends," said Azerbaijan-born Mr Ismayilov, who was the head of planning and commercial operations for BP in Azerbaijan, Georgia, Turkey, North Africa and the Middle East before moving to Australia last year.

"And that could grow to more than 20 per cent in a scenario consistent with the Paris climate goals," he added.

Meanwhile, Mr Ismayilov voiced strong support for the Woodside Petroleum-run Browse gas project to "unlock the next chapter of natural gas in Australia".

BP has a stake in both the Browse gas field and in the North West Shelf venture which is earmarked to process the gas. The two ventures are struggling to agree on the terms for processing Browse gas at the North West Shelf venture plant near Karratha, which is running out of its own gas.

"Browse is the largest undeveloped gas resource in Australia," said Mr Ismayilov, who also noted his experience in working within "complicated" ventures such as the North West Shelf from his previous role in the huge and complex Shah Deniz Stage 2 project in Azerbaijan, which involves six partners and crosses seven countries.

"As part of the Browse JV, BP is working with its partners and government to bring that gas down to Karratha and help keep the North West Shelf facilities full."

While BP walked away from the controversial Great Australian Bight exploration project off South Australia in 2016 it is continuing to explore and pursue developments off WA.

Mr Ismayilov pointed in particular to the Ironbark offshore prospect in the Carnarvon Basin, saying BP was "very excited" about the opportunity, where it is partnered by Cue Energy Resources, Beach Energy and New Zealand Oil and Gas.

The prospect, where an exploration well is targeted for late 2020, is close to North West Shelf offshore infrastructure.

"We are hopeful that it, too, will play a part in Australia’s ongoing natural gas prosperity," he said.
description: The British oil and gas major is also exploring hydrogen, solar and more gas development opportunities in line with its emissions reductions effort.
